items.title: Vaughan confused by 'amateurish' England plans before second Test
items.summary: Former England Test captain Michael Vaughan believes England's players need to take part in the England Lions' pink-ball multi-day match to help prepare for the second Ashes Test against Australia in Brisbane, following a damaging eight-wicket defeat in the first Test in Perth.

items.title: This hacker conference installed a literal antivirus monitoring system
items.summary: Organizers had a way for attendees to track CO2 levels throughout the venueâ€”even before they arrived.
items.body: Hacker conferencesâ€”like all conventionsâ€”are notorious for giving attendees a parting gift of mystery illness. To combat â€œcon crud,â€ New Zealandâ€™s premier hacker conference, Kawaiicon, quietly launched a real-time, room-by-room carbon dioxide monitoring system for attendees. To get the system up and running, event organizers installed DIY CO 2 monitors throughout the Michael Fowler Centre venue before conference doors opened on November 6. Attendees were able to check a public online dashboard for clean air readings for session rooms, kidsâ€™ areas, the front desk, and more, all before even showing up. â€œItâ€™s ALMOST like we are all nerds in a risk-based industry,â€ the organizers wrote on the conventionâ€™s website. â€œWhat they did is fantastic,â€ Jeff Moss, founder of the Defcon and Black Hat security conferences, told WIRED. â€œCO 2 is being used as an approximation for so many things, but there are no easy, inexpensive network monitoring solutions available. Kawaiicon building something to do this is the true spirit of hacking.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: Running an 1930s newspaper, foreseeing martial arts fights and other new indie games worth checking out
items.summary: Welcome to our latest roundup of what's going on in the indie game space. A whole bunch of intriguing games have arrived over the last week or so, and we got some tasty details on some upcoming projects, including one called Drywall Eating Simulator (trust me on this one). But first, an update on aâ€¦

items.title: England taken apart as brutal Head gives Australia opening Ashes win
items.summary: England go down to a humbling defeat in the first Ashes Test after Travis Headâ€™s blistering century completes an astonishing Australia fightback in Perth.

items.title: Ashes player ratings: Which England players got 1/10?

items.title: 'Half chance' Australia captain Cummins will return for second Ashes Test
items.summary: Australia captain Pat Cummins says he could be fit to return for the second Ashes Test next month.

items.title: 'Top class' - Head scores century as  Australia beat England
items.summary: Travis Head reaches his tenth Test century off just 69 balls as Australia beat England inside two days in the first Ashes Test in Perth.

items.title: Swansea to appoint Matos as Maritimo confirm move
items.summary: Swansea City are close to appointing Vitor Matos as their new head coach as his current club Maritimo confirm his departure.

items.title: Noakes goes from railways and roofing to Riyadh title shot
items.summary: Sam Noakes has run marathons on a whim and was moved to stop his mother from contacting past opponents - now he fights for the WBO lightweight title.

items.title: Scotland fans caused 'small earthquake' in World Cup qualifier win
items.summary: Seismic activity was recorded as the Tartan Army celebrated Scotland reaching their first World Cup since 1998.

items.title: A look around Barcelona's new-look Nou Camp
items.summary: BBC Spanish football reporter Elizabeth Conway shows us around Barcelona's iconic Nou Camp. The stadium will reopen, after more than two years of renovation work, for a game against Athletic Club in La Liga on Saturday.

items.title: Science-centric streaming service Curiosity Stream is an AI-licensing firm now
items.summary: Curiosity Stream's owner has more content for AI companies than it does for subscribers.
items.body: We all know streaming servicesâ€™ usual tricks for making more money: get more subscribers, charge those subscribers more money, and sell ads. But science streaming service Curiosity Stream is taking a new route that could reshape how streaming companies, especially niche options , try to survive. Discovery Channel founder John Hendricks launched Curiosity Stream in 2015. The streaming service costs $40 per year, and it doesnâ€™t have commercials. The streaming business has grown to also include the Curiosity Channel TV channel. CuriosityStream Inc. also makes money through original programming and its Curiosity University educational programming. The firm turned its first positive net income in its fiscal Q1 2025, after about a decade of business. Read full article Comments

items.title: Return to the year 2000 with classic multiplayer DOS games in your browser
items.summary: There are fan-made browser versions of Red Alert, Unreal Tournament, and more.
items.body: Over the past couple of weeks, friends and colleagues have made me aware of multiple ingeniously implemented, browser-based ways to play classic MS-DOS and Windows games with other people on basically any hardware. The late 1990s and early 2000s were the peak of multiplayer gaming for me. It was the era of real-time strategy games and boomer shooters, and not only did I attend many LAN parties, but I also played online with friends. Thatâ€™s still possible today with several old-school games; there are Discord servers that arrange scheduled matches of Starsiege Tribes , for example. But oftentimes, itâ€™s not exactly trivial to get those games running in modern Windows, and as in the old days, you might have some annoying network configuration work ahead of youâ€”to say nothing of the fact that many folks who were on Windows back in those days are now on macOS or Linux instead. Read full article Comments

items.title: How to know if your Asus router is one of thousands hacked by China-state hackers
items.summary: So far, the hackers are laying low, likely for later use.
items.body: Thousands of Asus routers have been hacked and are under the control of a suspected China-state group that has yet to reveal its intentions for the mass compromise, researchers said. The hacking spree is either primarily or exclusively targeting seven models of Asus routers, all of which are no longer supported by the manufacturer, meaning they no longer receive security patches, researchers from SecurityScorecard said . So far, itâ€™s unclear what the attackers do after gaining control of the devices. SecurityScorecard has named the operation WrtHug. Staying off the radar SecurityScorecard said it suspects the compromised devices are being used similarly to those found in ORB (operational relay box) networks, which hackers primarily use to conduct espionage to conceal their identity. Read full article Comments

items.title: Google tells employees it must double capacity every 6 months to meet AI demand
items.summary: Google's AI infrastructure chief tells staff it needs thousandfold capacity increase in 5 years.
items.body: While AI bubble talk fills the air these days, with fears of overinvestment that could pop at any time, something of a contradiction is brewing on the ground: Companies like Google and OpenAI can barely build infrastructure fast enough to fill their AI needs. During an all-hands meeting earlier this month, Googleâ€™s AI infrastructure head Amin Vahdat told employees that the company must double its serving capacity every six months to meet demand for artificial intelligence services, reports CNBC. Vahdat, a vice president at Google Cloud, presented slides showing the company needs to scale â€œthe next 1000x in 4-5 years.â€ While a thousandfold increase in compute capacity sounds ambitious by itself, Vahdat noted some key constraints: Google needs to be able to deliver this increase in capability, compute, and storage networking â€œfor essentially the same cost and increasingly, the same power, the same energy level,â€ he told employees during the meeting. â€œIt wonâ€™t be easy but through collaboration and co-design, weâ€™re going to get there.â€ Read full article Comments

items.title: AI trained on bacterial genomes produces never-before-seen proteins
items.summary: Genes with related functions cluster together, and the AI uses that.
items.body: AI systems have recently had a lot of success in one key aspect of biology: the relationship between a proteinâ€™s structure and its function. These efforts have included the ability to predict the structure of most proteins and to design proteins structured so that they perform useful functions . But all of these efforts are focused on the proteins and amino acids that build them. But biology doesnâ€™t generate new proteins at that level. Instead, changes have to take place at the nucleic acid level before eventually making their presence felt at the protein level. And the DNA level is fairly removed from proteins, with lots of critical non-coding sequences, redundancy, and a fair degree of flexibility. Itâ€™s not necessarily obvious that learning the organization of a genome would help an AI system figure out how to make functional proteins. But it now seems like using bacterial genomes for the training can help develop a system that can predict proteins, some of which donâ€™t look like anything weâ€™ve ever seen before. Read full article Comments

items.summary: Four arrested and charged with illegal exports, smuggling, and money laundering.
items.body: The US crackdown on chip exports to China has continued with the arrests of four people accused of a conspiracy to illegally export Nvidia chips. Two US citizens and two nationals of the Peopleâ€™s Republic of China (PRC), all of whom live in the US, were charged in an indictment unsealed on Wednesday in US District Court for the Middle District of Florida. The indictment alleges a scheme to send Nvidia â€œGPUs to China by falsifying paperwork, creating fake contracts, and misleading US authorities,â€ John Eisenberg, assistant attorney general for the Justice Departmentâ€™s National Security Division, said in a press release yesterday. The four arrestees are Hon Ning Ho (aka Mathew Ho), a US citizen who was born in Hong Kong and lives in Tampa, Florida; Brian Curtis Raymond, a US citizen who lives in Huntsville, Alabama; Cham Li (aka Tony Li), a PRC national who lives in San Leandro, California; and Jing Chen (aka Harry Chen), a PRC national who lives in Tampa on an F-1 non-immigrant student visa. items.title: Data-driven sport: How Oracle Red Bull Racing and AT&T move terabytes of F1 info
items.summary: Since the last time we spoke to the F1 team, its cars have 3 times as many sensors on them.
items.body: AT&T provided flights from Washington, DC, to Las Vegas and accommodation so Ars could attend the Las Vegas Grand Prix. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. LAS VEGASâ€”A Formula 1 car runs on soon-to-be-synthetic gasoline, but an F1 team runs on data. Itâ€™s always been an engineering-driven sport, and while you can make decisions based on a hunch, the kinds of people who become good engineers prefer something a little more convincing. And the volumes of data just continue to get bigger and bigger each season. A few years ago, we spoke to Red Bull Racing about how it stayed on top of the task, but a lot has changed in F1 since 2017, as we found out at this yearâ€™s Las Vegas Grand Prix. Itâ€™s hugely popular now, for one thing, even in the United States: a 200 mph soap opera now with 24 episodes a season. Superficially, the cars look the sameâ€”exposed wheels, front and rear wings, the driver in between some side pods. And the hybrid powertrains that make the cars move are still the same format: 1.6 L turbocharged V6 engines that recover energy from the rear wheels under braking as well as the turbine as it gets spun by hot exhaust gases. But the cars are actually fundamentally â€¦

items.body: For months, the Trump administration has warned that semiconductor tariffs are coming soon, leaving the tech industry on pins and needles after a chaotic year of unpredictable tariff regimes collectively cost firms billions. The semiconductor tariffs are key to Donald Trumpâ€™s economic agenda, which is intended to force more manufacturing into the US by making it more expensive to import materials and products. He campaigned on axing the CHIPS Act â€”which provided subsidies to companies investing in manufacturing chips in the USâ€”complaining that it was a â€œhorrible, horrible thingâ€ to â€œgive hundreds of billions of dollarsâ€ away when the US could achieve the same objective by instead taxing companies and â€œuse whatever is left overâ€ of CHIPS funding to â€œreduce debt.â€ However, as 2025 winds down, the US president faces pressure on all sides to delay semiconductor tariffs, insiders told Reuters , and it appears that he is considering caving. According to â€œtwo people with direct knowledge of the matter and a third person briefed on the conversations,â€ US officials have privately told industry and government stakeholders that semiconductor tariffs will likely be delayed. items.title: Chris Hemsworth and dad fight Alzheimerâ€™s with a trip down memory lane
items.summary: Ars chats with director Tom Barbor-Might about new National Geographic documentary A Road Trip to Remember.
items.body: Millions of people around the world are living with the harsh reality of Alzheimerâ€™s disease, which also significantly impacts family members. Nobody is immune, as A-list actor Chris Hemsworth discovered when his own father was recently diagnosed. The revelation inspired Hemsworth to embark on a trip down memory lane with his father, which took them to Australiaâ€™s Northern Territory . The experience was captured on film for A Road Trip to Remember, a new documentary film from National Geographic. Director Tom Barbor-Might had worked with Hemsworth on the latterâ€™s documentary series Limitless , also for National Geographic. Each episode of Limitless follows Hemsworth on a unique challenge to push himself to the limits, augmented with interviews with scientific experts on such practices as fasting, extreme temperatures, brain-boosting, and regulating oneâ€™s stress response. Barbor-Might directed the season 1 finale, â€œAcceptance,â€ which was very different in tone, dealing with the inevitability of death and the need to confront oneâ€™s own mortality. â€œIt was really interesting to see Chris in that more intimate personal space, and he was great at it,â€ Barbor-Might told Ars. â€œHe was charâ€¦

items.title: First revealed in spy photos, a Bronze Age city emerges from the steppe
items.summary: An unexpectedly large city lies in a sea of grass inhabited largely by nomads.
items.body: Today all thatâ€™s left of the ancient city of Semiyarka are a few low earthen mounds and some scattered artifacts, nearly hidden beneath the waving grasses of the Kazakh Steppe, a vast swath of grassland that stretches across northern Kazakhstan and into Russia. But recent surveys and excavations reveal that 3,500 years ago, this empty plain was a bustling city with a thriving metalworking industry, where nomadic herders and traders might have mingled with settled metalworkers and merchants. Radivojevic and Lawrence stand on the site of Semiyarka. Credit: Peter J. Brown Welcome to the City of Seven Ravines University College of London archaeologist Miljana Radivojevic and her colleagues recently mapped the site with drones and geophysical surveys (like ground-penetrating radar, for example), tracing the layout of a 140-hectare city on the steppe in whatâ€™s now Kazakhstan. The Bronze Age city once boasted rows of houses built on earthworks, a large central building, and a neighborhood of workshops where artisans smelted and cast bronze. From its windswept promontory, it held a commanding view of a narrow point in the Irtysh River valley, a strategic location that may have offered theâ€¦

items.title: Low-cost MacBook and more launching in Q1 2026, report says
items.summary: Analyst Jeff Pu is out with a new investor note today with details on Appleâ€™s timeline for new product launches over the next year. In the investor note, seen by 9to5Mac, Pu says that Apple will kick off 2026 with the launch of three new low-cost products: the iPhone 17e, a low-cost MacBook, and anâ€¦

items.title: Newest Starship booster is significantly damaged during testing early Friday
items.summary: SpaceX had big plans for the upgraded Starship vehicle that failed on Friday morning.
items.body: During the pre-dawn hours in South Texas on Friday morning, SpaceXâ€™s next-generation Starship first stage suffered some sort of major damage during pre-launch testing. The company had only rolled the massive rocket out of the factory a day earlier, noting the beginning of its test campaign, it said on the social media site X : â€œThe first operations will test the boosterâ€™s redesigned propellant systems and its structural strength.â€ That testing commenced on Thursday night at the Masseyâ€™s Test Site a couple of miles down the road from the companyâ€™s main production site at Starbase Texas. However an independent video showed the rocketâ€™s lower half undergo an explosive (or possibly implosive) event at 4:04 am CT (10:04 UTC) Friday. Read full article Comments

items.title: Stoke Space goes for broke to solve the only launch problem that â€œmoves the needleâ€
items.summary: "Does the world really need a 151st rocket company?"
items.body: LAUNCH COMPLEX 14, Cape Canaveral, Fla.â€”The platform atop the hulking steel tower offered a sweeping view of Floridaâ€™s rich, sandy coastline and brilliant blue waves beyond. Yet as captivating as the vista might be for an aspiring rocket magnate like Andy Lapsa, it also had to be a little intimidating. To his right, at Launch Complex 13 next door, a recently returned Falcon 9 booster stood on a landing pad. SpaceX has landed more than 500 large orbital rockets. And next to SpaceX sprawled the launch site operated by Blue Origin. Its massive New Glenn rocket is also reusable, and founder Jeff Bezos has invested tens of billions of dollars into the venture. Looking to the left, Lapsa saw a graveyard of sorts for commercial startups. Launch Complex 15 was leased to a promising startup, ABL Space, two years ago. After two failed launches, ABL Space pivoted away from commercial launch. Just beyond lies Launch Complex 16, where Relativity Space aims to launch from. The company has already burned through $1.7 billion in its efforts to reach orbit. Had billionaire Eric Schmidt not stepped in earlier this year, Relativity would have gone bankrupt. Read full article Comments

items.title: HP and Dell disable HEVC support built into their laptopsâ€™ CPUs
items.summary: HEVC licensing gets more expensive in January.
items.body: Some Dell and HP laptop owners have been befuddled by their machinesâ€™ inability to play HEVC/H.265 content in web browsers, despite their machinesâ€™ processors having integrated decoding support. Laptops with sixth-generation Intel Core and later processors have built-in hardware support for HEVC decoding and encoding. AMD has made laptop chips supporting the codec since 2015 . However, both Dell and HP have disabled this feature on some of their popular business notebooks. HP discloses this in the data sheets for its affected laptops, which include the HP ProBook 460 G11 [ PDF ], ProBook 465 G11 [ PDF ], and EliteBook 665 G11 [ PDF] . Read full article Comments

items.title: Infant botulism outbreak doubles; ByHeart confirms bacteria in formula
items.summary: ByHeart said "there's no reason to believe" until its own testing found a reason.
items.body: ByHeart announced on Thursday that its own testing identified the bacterium that causes botulism in its baby formula, which is linked to an ongoing infant botulism outbreak that has doubled since last week. As of November 19, there have been 31 cases across 15 states â€”up from 15 cases in 12 states reported last week. All 31 cases so far have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported. The outbreak was announced on November 8, and ByHeart was, at first, unusually aggressive in deflecting blame for linked illnesses. Read full article Comments

items.title: Microsoft makes Zork I, II, and III open source under MIT License
items.summary: Microsoft's Open Source Programs Office worked with Jason Scott to do it.
items.body: Zork , the classic text-based adventure game of incalculable influence , has been made available under the MIT License, along with the sequels Zork II and Zork III . The move to take these Zork games open source comes as the result of the shared work of the Xbox and Activision teams along with Microsoftâ€™s Open Source Programs Office (OSPO). Parent company Microsoft owns the intellectual property for the franchise. Only the code itself has been made open source. Ancillary items like commercial packaging and marketing assets and materials remain proprietary, as do related trademarks and brands. Read full article Comments

items.summary: We are now less than 24 hours out from the official start of Amazonâ€™s Black Friday sale â€“ get a sneak peek at the deals here â€“ but it is already serving some serious price matches and deep discounts right now. The entire M4 MacBook Air lineup has now dropped a touch lower starting from $749 and we â€¦

items.title: macOS 26.2 adds three new Mac features, hereâ€™s whatâ€™s coming
items.summary: macOS Tahoe 26.2 is launching next month for all users, hereâ€™s an overview of three new features it brings to the Mac. moreâ€¦

items.title: New limited-time Apple Card offer now available: Earn $75 in Daily Cash [U]
items.summary: Once again, Apple has dropped a limited time Apple Card offer for new users who choose to sign up. Typically, the Apple Card does not offer a sign up bonus, so this is worth looking into. moreâ€¦

items.title: Google's Gemini 3 model keeps the AI hype train going â€“ for now
items.summary: Googleâ€™s latest model reportedly beats its rivals in several benchmark tests, but issues with reliability mean concerns remain over a possible AI bubble

items.title: Next yearâ€™s iPhone 18 decision could be very hard for almost everyone
items.summary: Itâ€™s the time of year when Apple finalizes many key details about next fallâ€™s flagship iPhone lineup, and recent leaks indicate the iPhone 18 line could present an especially tough upgrade decision for almost all users. moreâ€¦

items.title: The EU is fixing the most annoying thing on the web
items.summary: The EUâ€™s landmark privacy law, GDPR, was one of the best things to happen to the internet for a very long time. But it also came with one of the most annoying things on the web: a never-ending series of pop-ups asking us to make cookie choices â€¦ moreâ€¦

items.title: Quantum computers that recycle their qubits can limit errors
items.summary: To make quantum computers more efficient and reliable, some of their basic components must be constantly reused â€“ several quantum computer designs can now do just that

items.title: More iPhone users can add their driverâ€™s license to Apple Wallet starting today
items.summary: Update November 19: This feature is now live. Illinois residents can now head to the Wallet app to add their licenses. Original story below. Apple Wallet support for digital driverâ€™s licenses and state IDs continues to expand. Now, Illinois has officially announced that starting tomorrow, iPhone usâ€¦

items.title: A cluster of Mac Studios is just one reason we no longer need a Mac Pro
items.summary: Back in the Intel days, the Mac Pro was the computer many of us lusted over even if we had no possible justification for actually buying one. It was by far the most powerful Mac and the easiest to upgrade â€“ not to mention one of the most beautiful machines the company ever made. The 2023 Mac Pro waâ€¦

items.title: Here are the 2025 App Store Awards finalists
items.summary: As we approach the end of 2025, Apple is gearing up to unveil the winners of the 2025 App Store Awards. As part of that process, Apple today announced the 45 finalists for the App Store Awards. The nominations span a wide range of categories. Head below for the full list. moreâ€¦

items.title: TikTok says badges are a solution to teenage app addiction
items.summary: With a growing number of legislators wanting to set limits on the use of social media apps by teenagers and children, TikTok is hitting back. The company argues â€“ with an apparently straight face â€“ that new features like an affirmation journal, background sound generator, and app badges are likely â€¦

items.title: Cloudflare explains the mistake that took down large chunks of the internet yesterday
items.summary: Huge chunks of the internet were completely unavailable yesterday, with many other websites and services experiencing slow performance. It was immediately clear that the problem was with the Cloudflare network, but it took some time for the company to establish the true cause. Cloudflare says that â€¦

items.title: Gentler Streak rolls out Weekly Activity Recaps

items.summary: Comments

items.title: The engrossing biopic of a Hollywood icon's early years
items.summary: Based on a true story, starring Toby Jones, Lesley Manville and Harry Lawtey

items.summary: Thousands of holes arranged in a snake-like pattern on Monte Sierpe in Peru could have been a monumental accounting device for trade and tax

items.title: Is a robot programmed to prank you annoying? Yes

items.summary: Lise BarnÃ©oud's Hidden Guests shows how this fascinating new field brings with it profound implications for medicine, and even what it means to be human, finds Helen Thomson

items.summary: A planet is about to be destroyed by the collapse of a binary star system in Slow Gods, Claire Northâ€™s first venture into classic science fiction. Read it! says Emily H. Wilson
